Introduction

title: PICA Data Model
text:
Specification
This chapter defines the data model of PICA+.
A collection is a (possibly empty) sequence of records.
A record is a non-empty sequence of fields. The fields are sorted as described below.
A field is a pair of a field identifier and a non-empty list of subfields.
A field identifier consists of a tag, optionally followed by a slash (/) followed by an occurrence.
A tag is a sequence of four characters:
An occurrence is a sequence of two or three digits, excluding sequences of zeroes only. Occurrences of fields in level 1 and 2 MUST have two digits only.
A subfield is a pair of subfield code and subfield value.
A subfield code is one of the characters A-Z, a-z and 0-9.
A subfield value is a sequence of bytes not including any of the control codes (#x00 to #x1F). Subfield values SHOULD be valid sequences Unicode code points encoded in UTF-8.

title: PICA Normalized
text:
Specification
PICA Normalized is the preferred machine-readable serialization of PICA records (although not widely used by OCLC CBS/LBS). Each record is stored on a line. PICA fields end with byte code #x1E and subfields start with byte code #x1F.
The URI of PICA Normalized is https://format.gbv.de/pica/normalized.
Collection, record, field, field identifier, subfields, subfield code and subfield value are defined by the PICA Data Model.
A collection is encoded as sequence of encoded records, separated by a line feed (#x0A). The last record MAY be terminated by an additional newline character (#x0A). A record is encoded as sequence of fields, each encoded as sequence of:

title: PICA Normalized
text:
the field identifier
a space (#x20)
the list of subfields, each the subfield indicator #x1F followed by the subfield code followed by the subfield value
the byte #x1E

title: PICA Plain
text:
Specification
PICA Normalized is the preferred human-readable serialization of PICA records. Each field is on one line, records are separated by empty lines and subfield start with $.
The URI of PICA Plain is https://format.gbv.de/pica/plain.
Collection, record, field, field identifier, subfields, subfield code and subfield value are defined by the PICA Data Model.
A collection is encoded as sequence of encoded records, separated by one or more empty lines. An empty line consists of nothing but a line feed (#x0A). Additional empty lines are allowed before the first and after the last record.
A record is encoded as sequence of fields, each encoded as sequence of
The final line feed of the last field of the last record MAY be omitted.
Applications MAY allow an additional carriage return (#x0D) before a line feed (#x0A) and sequences of space (#x20) and/or tabulator (#x09) before the line feed of empty lines.

title: PICA Plain
text:
the field identifier
a space (#x20)
the list of subfields, each the character $ (#x24) followed by the subfield value with every character $ replaced by a sequence of two $$
a line feed (#xA0)

title: PICA XML
text:
Specification
PICA XML (without XML Namespace) was introduced in the early 2000s to serve PICA+ records via SRU. In 2006 the format was documented at VZG with XML Namespace and XML Schema, and a stable version 1.0 was published at July 3rd, 20081. OCLC decided against officially adopting it, so alternative forms of encoding PICA in XML have evolved.
PICA XML is listed at https://www.loc.gov/standards/sru/recordSchemas/ with identifier info:srw/schema/5/picaXML-v1.0.

Listing 6.1: Formal grammar of PICA Path


path              ::=  ( tag | xtag ) occurrence? subfields?
tag               ::=  [012.] [0-9.] [0-9.] [A-Z@.]
xtag              ::=  "2" [0-9.] [0-9.] [A-Z@.] "x" number
occurrence        ::=  "/" occurrenceValue
occurrenceValue   ::=  number ( "-" number )? | "*"
subfields         ::=  [$.]? ( [A-Za-z0-9]+ | "*" )
number            ::=  [0-9]+
